entry.title: A (Pointed) Guide to Beer
entry.content:
The slideshow below contains my slides from LRUG‚Äôs 13 February lightning talk meet-up. If you missed the meet-up, I‚Äôd highly recommend watching some of the talks at that link‚Äîparticularly Lola‚Äôs talk about finding your dream job, and Paul‚Äôs bizarre journey through balanced ternary. I would not, however, recommend watching my talk. If you‚Äôd like to learn a bit about beer, the outline here will give you a decent overview and touch on everything included in the talk. If you‚Äôd like to learn about why I hated giving a talk and never want to do it again, well, there‚Äôs a place for that too.

So, beer. I‚Äôve been a beer snob for as long as I can remember. After I moved to London a couple of years ago, I started working for BrewDog, who are big proponents of the Cicerone certification program.

As a Certified Cicerone, I have a greater-than-average depth of knowledge about beer: serving, storage, brewing, history, beer styles, pairing with food, off-flavours, et cetera. When faced with a 10-minute time slot and a staggering breadth of existing knowledge to draw upon, I opted to provide a general overview: enough detail that most people might learn something new, but a simple enough starting point that I felt reasonably confident I wouldn‚Äôt lose anyone‚Äôs interest right off the bat. So, without further ado, here‚Äôs the outline of the talk. You can download a PDF of these slides if you‚Äôd like.

A (Pointed) Guide to Beer

Why // When // How

Why drink beer?

  • Brewing is a craft which requires precision, creativity, and attention to detail‚Äî much like coding!
  • Beer goes well with food. A good food and beer pairing can be a magical experience, evoking emotional response or feelings of nostalgia. Unexpected pairings can enable you to perceive flavours you wouldn‚Äôt expect to find in both food and beer.
  • It contains alcohol, which lower inhibitions. Some people like that.

When to drink beer? This is a trick question. There‚Äôs no wrong time to drink beer.

How should one drink beer? There are many ways to drink beer, but Ruby is all about a single opinionated approach, so this is presentation contains strong opinions.

Drinking beer at a pub

  • It‚Äôs important to find the right kind of pub‚Äîmany taps, or a long, handwritten list of beers, breweries, and ABVs on a blackboard are good indicators.
  • If you‚Äôre in a pub that doesn‚Äôt have good beer, my recommendation is to order a gin & tonic instead. Bad beer is a waste of time.
  • Once you‚Äôre in the right place, ask for a taste of something that sounds interesting.
  • If you really don‚Äôt know where to start, chat with the bartender for a bit. Bartenders in good beer bars generally know about beer and can tell you what‚Äôs tasting good at the moment.
  • Get a recommendation. If you describe 2-3 beers you know you like, the bartender can probably recommend something similar for you to try.
  • Try something new! New beers are released all the time. It‚Äôs tempting to get stuck in a rut and order the same thing every time once you‚Äôve found something you like, but that‚Äôs pretty dumb. Don‚Äôt do that. Try new things.
  • Beer can range in ABV from 0.5% to 40%+ for some ice-distilled varieties, so be careful and pay attention to the ABV when you‚Äôre ordering. Don‚Äôt be stupid, remember to drink water or eat something if you‚Äôre drinking a lot of strong beers.
  • Don‚Äôt be a dick. This is where I ‚Äúsubtly‚Äù pointed out that if your bartender is giving you a lot of tasters and great recommendations, they‚Äôll be incentivised to continue providing that kind of service (which they‚Äôre not obligated to provide) if you engage in this practice some parts of the world call ‚Äútipping‚Äù. Don‚Äôt knock it ‚Äòtil you‚Äôve tried it.

How to drink beer, Part 2: Appreciating beer requires a balance of four main senses: Appearance, Aroma, Mouthfeel, and Taste

Appearance

  • Beer colour is measured in degrees SRM (standard reference measure), ranging from 1 for very light lager to 40+ for black beers.
  • Most beer styles should have perfect clarity, but unfiltered, hazy beers are becoming rather common among London craft breweries. Some classic styles, like Hefeweizen, are intentionally cloudy.
  • If you see bubbles clustering on the inside of your glass, congratulations, the bar you‚Äôre drinking in has dirty glassware. Bummer.

Aroma

  • Aroma is delivered from the beer to your nose in the little bubbles of carbon dioxide that pop on the surface.
  • Swirl the beer in the glass to generate a bit of foamy head, activating aromatic compounds.
  • Take a few small sniffs, then a deeper inhalation. If you get too acclimated to the aroma and can‚Äôt detect it as well, try sniffing the back of your hand to reset your nose.
  • Most of the aroma in beer comes from hops added late in the brewing process.
  • Hop aromas vary widely depending on the variety. Some common hop aromas you might encounter include citrus (lemon, grapefruit, orange), tropical (passionfruit, pineapple), grassy/herbal/floral, pine, mint, marijuana (typically described as ‚Äúdank‚Äù).

Mouthfeel

  • Take a sip of the (hypothetical) beer, swirl it around in your mouth and over the tongue
  • The sensation left in your mouth in referred to as ‚Äúmouthfeel‚Äù. Does it coat your tongue? Dry out your mouth?
  • High carbonation/more fizz creates a drier, crisper mouthfeel.
  • More sugar and heavier body make for a richer mouthfeel.
  • Mouthfeel is one of the most important factors in pairing beer with food.

Taste

  • Five elements of beer taste are sweet, sour, salty, bitter, umami.
  • Bitterness is the big one, derived from hops added early in the boil.
  • Sweetness generally comes from malted barley.
  • Salt flavour can come from minerals in the brewing water or can be added for certain styles.
  • Umami is generally not a great flavour to find in beer; it can indicate autolysed yeast.
  • Sour beers are my favourite! Sourness can come from the yeast strain or from added bacteria.
  • There‚Äôs an important difference between good sour(deliberate) and bad sourness, such as from infected beer or dirty draught lines.

How to buy beer for a poker night

  • Buy from local shops and local breweries: Kew, Beavertown, Kernel are all great options.
  • Lower ABV beers are usually more cost-effective.
  • Classic styles like lager, pale ale, IPA are safe bets and go well with snacks.
  • It‚Äôs more important to have enough beer than to have expensive beer.
  • Be nice to your guests: Provide appropriate glassware if the beer is unfiltered; no one likes a mouth full of yeast.
  • Check the dates to make sure your beers are fresh! IPAs and pale ales are best within six months of bottling (the younger the better). Hop aroma fades quickly and very old hops can take on a cheesy smell that most people find deeply unpleasant.
  • If your friends don‚Äôt appreciate good beer, save some money and buy crappy beer for them.
  • Yes, they will probably just drink your good beer anyway. If that happens, save the bad beers and use them to make beer bread or micheladas.
  • It can be distracting to fuss over fancy beer, so don‚Äôt get anything too special if the purpose of your gathering is to play poker or watch sports.

How to pair beer with food if you‚Äôre going to dinner at your boss‚Äôs house or something

  • Pairing beer with food is really tough if you don‚Äôt know the menu in advance.
  • The best option is to just buy Belgian beer, since it goes well with food.
  • Belgian yeast strains have fruity, spicy, peppery notes that bring out complementary flavours in food.
  • Saison is a particularly good option‚Äîgoes well with cheese, meats, vegetables.
  • They tend to be pretty strong, so if you want something lower ABV, keep an eye out for ‚Äútable saison‚Äù, also known as grisette.

Beer for dessert? Sadly saison doesn‚Äôt go very well with chocolate. Pick out a nice imperial stout or barleywine to go with dessert.

entry.title: On the Cult of Giving Talks

link.title: On the Cult of Giving Talks

entry.content:
I recently gave my first‚Äîand quite possibly, last‚Äîtalk at a tech meet-up. While I‚Äôm grateful to LRUG for the opportunity to speak, and to the London Ruby community for being a charitable audience, giving a talk wasn‚Äôt an experience I enjoyed. I have conflicted feelings about this realisation, which I‚Äôm sharing in case others find themselves in a similar position.

On the one hand, I‚Äôm very early in my tech career and still in what I‚Äôve fondly come to think of as ‚ÄúThe Magpie Phase.‚Äù My interest and attention are piqued by each shiny new thing I learn about. It‚Äôs a nice change of pace to want to rule something out as a potential area of interest, rather than being distracted by the latest CSS grid or Raspberry Pi when my time would be better spent on core foundational skills.

On the other hand, it feels as though there‚Äôs some pressure in the field to give talks, particularly if you‚Äôre from an underrepresented group (e.g., if you‚Äôre not a cisgender straight white male). The perceived lack of diverse speakers is frequently trotted out as an excuse when conference organisers fail to put together a diverse lineup of speakers. I‚Äôm always happy to see women on stage as speakers, and it feels a bit hypocritical to be unwilling to be one of those women.

I‚Äôm good at speaking extemporaneously, enjoy crafting a narrative, and have a lot of collected random bits of knowledge about various interesting topics. On paper, I should be an excellent candidate for giving talks. The talk I gave was about beer, a subject about which I can speak at length without any preparation (or even any prompting, if I happen to have a beer in my hand). It‚Äôs not a technical topic, so the imposter syndrome that dogs me on a daily basis doesn‚Äôt really come into play. I‚Äôve had to dig pretty deep to try to unpack why I hated being up on stage, but I think I‚Äôve finally hit on it: It all comes back to karaoke.

A large majority of my friends love karaoke. They get together on a regular basis at their favourite karaoke bars. They practice their songs, trying out new material or polishing up old stand-bys. They put on a show, entertaining the audience, the other singers, and themselves. And as far as I can tell, they do this because they just really love it. They love the attention, they love performing, they love entertaining.

This aspect of giving talks‚Äîthe part that relies on showmanship, being able to capture and hold an audience‚Äôs attention‚Äîis the part that makes me feel like my whole body is being dunked in boiling oil or eaten alive by tropical ants. I don‚Äôt mind being the centre of attention for a specific purpose, but being on a stage with the expectation of entertaining people, well, that‚Äôs never been my M.O. I despise karaoke.

I know that if I were to give a second talk at some point, I‚Äôve learned a few things and would do a better job. It‚Äôs possible I would have enjoyed this more if I were speaking on a technical topic. I almost certainly would have felt more comfortable if I‚Äôd arrived early and tested my speaking volume with the microphone. I should have brought my own laptop, so I could have run my slides in presentation mode, with my notes visible on a screen for me but hidden for the audience. As it was, I presented without notes, which would have been fine were the timing not quite so tight.

But what I really want to know is: Must I? Is there any compelling reason I should put myself through this experience again? Ultimately, I‚Äôm perfectly happy to leave the entertaining to people who love the limelight‚Ä¶ and that realisation is probably the most valuable lesson I can take from this experience.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
I started out following the quick-start guide on Jekyll docs:

{% highlight bash %} $ gem install jekyll $ jekyll new $ jekyll serve {% endhighlight %}

As I read further through the docs and admired my new creation, I quickly realised I was going to be making a lot of changes to the default set-up, even for the simple site I had in mind. After copying over the layout files from the minima gem to my site folder, I set about pruning code, poking around, and observing how everything is put together.

I‚Äôm still learning! Parts of it feel familiar. Jekyll uses Liquid syntax, which feels familiar after using Django at my last job. It‚Äôs far more powerful than I need for a site this simple, but it‚Äôs fun to have a sandbox to play around in.

However, I‚Äôve only just realised that Liquid is part of the Shopify family. I don‚Äôt have much experience with Shopify; all I know of them is that they provide the platform for most of the revenue to America‚Äôs fascist media outlet‚Ä¶ so now I feel much less great about how I spent my Saturday afternoon. üòï
